text: [MUSIC PLAYING]

GUEST SPEAKER: I thought that
would be a very interesting way

to get people of different
ages, different backgrounds,

different artistic
abilities to all work

together for a
cultural thing that

could also be a good lead in to
tourists learning more about--

JACK: So the float is coming
from somewhere to here.

PROFESSOR: No, it's
being built here, Jack.

GUEST SPEAKER: It's
being made in here.

JACK: The float is built
here and going out.

GUEST SPEAKER: It's
built in here, exactly.
JACK: You're sending floats out.
GUEST SPEAKER: Exactly.

So this whole direction that's
created here is so that--

JACK: Well, how does
it get out the door?

GUEST SPEAKER: Well,
it's a really big door.
It's 15 feet tall, actually.

And the area inside is
this whole big area,

so there's a lot of
room for it to be--

JACK: So that's the
float making [INAUDIBLE]..
GUEST SPEAKER: Yes.

And my visualization
of how this would

work is take however many
months to make the float,

and then the day that
it's unveiled people
would come and sit along here.
And this is a cafe.
JACK: Cheer and yell.

GUEST SPEAKER: Cheer and
watch, and they'd all come out.

And they'd go up North
Street, down Hanover,
and come back round.

And this is actually a
graveyard for the old floats.

JACK: So send something out
from here into the world

and have then people
drawn back to it.
GUEST SPEAKER: Exactly.
JACK: Can you eat here?
GUEST SPEAKER: Yes.
I was just about to explain.

PROFESSOR: And you
can see a movie, Jack.

GUEST SPEAKER: And you
can see a movie, yes.
You can do a lot.

So I was imagining
tourists are generally

walking from Government Center,
Quincy Market-type areas.

So they'd find themselves
on this ramp going up
to my building.

Sidewalk sort of merges
gently, so they'd
be in there no matter what.

JACK: Little Carpenter
Center trick, yeah.
GUEST SPEAKER: Yes, exactly.

And they'd find themselves
on this first floor.

Well, actually it
leads them up to here,

which is the museum, so
right in here, so the museum.

And they can look directly
into the float museum area.
JACK: Museum about float making.

GUEST SPEAKER: Museum
about float making, just

general North End
culture of the arts.

And so they could walk actually
through where the floats are

being made and look
down and watch and come

into Moore Museum, which is then
connected to the movie theater,

and they can go watch
Italian cinema, for example.

And for the people
on the North End,

they're coming more
from this direction,

I imagine, and be led
into this building, which

is where there's the wood
shops and the metal shops
and whatever.
JACK: [INAUDIBLE] shop, right.

PROFESSOR: Which all open
out into the float museum.

GUEST SPEAKER: And to
the float building areas.

And you can continue
upstairs, past the museum

to the third floor,
where there's

a couple of smaller workshop
areas for people who just

want to build their own thing,
not necessarily for the floats.

And then on top of the
theater, on the third floor,

there's the cafe onto this
balcony area right in here,
exactly.

And then we have
little garden areas.
I was trying to--

as Sarah probably
told you, there's
a lack of light in this area.
JACK: It's a shaded garden.

GUEST SPEAKER:
Well, I was trying

to I incorporated some
water, or something, maybe
that would help.

Also the siding for
the arts building

was actually the
reflecting glass.

I don't know exactly
what it's called.

So you wouldn't
be able to see it,

but it would hopefully be
reflecting the light that
actually appears.

So this wood here
is actually glass.
And these came about--

actually, I don't quite know
how these exact ones came about.

I knew I wanted to capture
the light that came in.

I wanted it to show
that something was
special was happening in here.

And they're made of translucent
materials and copper.

They're obviously
hung off the building.

JACK: It seems like they were
coming out of this building.
GUEST SPEAKER: Yeah.

Even in my junk
model, you can see

I was playing with direction
of the tourists, direction

of the North End,
something somewhat normal,
and then something happening.

JACK: That's not
quite as coherent--
confluent as this flow.
GUEST SPEAKER: Yeah.

PROFESSOR: This one
has something happening

and this one has something
coming out of the building.
GUEST SPEAKER: Yes.

JACK: Now, this,
on the other hand,

seems to be coming out of this
building like this, to me,
and so doing that.
GUEST SPEAKER: Right.
Yes.

JACK: And then there's this
fellow, who didn't make it
but went a long way.
GUEST SPEAKER: Yes.

Him I was actually trying
to connect to this street

because I was imagining
floats coming out
and going to Hanover.

Or if not, they'd just come
out and go up the street.

JACK: It would have been
fun to have it do that.
GUEST SPEAKER: Turn the corner.
JACK: Well, to enter there.
GUEST SPEAKER: Yeah.
I don't know, I keep debating.

PROFESSOR: The
cafe thing would be

a better draw for people to
jump in and just have a coffee

or see somebody on the thing
if we're down there on the left
or down in here or something.

JACK: I think the street level
might be a terrific attractor,

and then get tables
out onto the space.
PROFESSOR: Right about here.
GUEST SPEAKER: Yeah.
JACK: Maybe right there.
Yeah.
GUEST SPEAKER: Yeah.
My initial just--

I was trying to connect
[INAUDIBLE] what do they need?
They need supplies.
JACK: Right.

PROFESSOR: Well,
maybe the art store's

up here, that you bring
people through the whole--

JACK: Or sell food
and art supplies.

PROFESSOR: I also
like the fact that you

have, as Jack has
described it, established

a very clear relationship to
this thing and to this thing.

So you've connected
yourself to the context.

I think you could have connected
yourself even more strongly

if you had expressed what
is there, which we've
seen over there as being a dam.

And then you could have
either related to it
or decided not to relate to it.
But here I don't know.

It's just coming up to
the wall and stopping.

Could those carry through
into whatever this is?
Or how is this thing--

JACK: Generate
through the source.
PROFESSOR: Yeah.
Yes.
GUEST SPEAKER: Sure.

PROFESSOR: How is this
thing generating that thing?
Where's this coming from?

JOHN: That configuration
and then this
would be a wonderful connection.
I like that.

GUEST SPEAKER:
Well, that's true.

I totally ignored [LAUGHS]
what that [INAUDIBLE]..
PROFESSOR: This seems OK to me.

I can imagine this stuff
being much like this stuff.

JOHN: Is that a shop
in the bottom here?

GUEST SPEAKER: This
is just a townhouse.
JOHN: Just a what?

GUEST SPEAKER: A
townhouse, a four-story--
JOHN: Apartment.
GUEST SPEAKER: Exactly.

JOHN: There's-- just as
a kind of small comment,

sometimes you can make
spaces and they're wonderful.
And that is.
I really like it.

But sometimes you
have elements that

come together and
make a space which
I don't like to think about.

I don't like to think about the
space that's just under there.
GUEST SPEAKER: Yeah.
Yeah.
I was hoping--
I don't know.

Because initially
I wanted this plane

to be for the artists
that are working here

and this plane to be for the
tourists that are coming out

of the movie theater
and the cafe.

JOHN: I'm just talking
about the 2-foot-high space.
That's it.
GUEST SPEAKER: Yeah, exactly.
That's one of the problem areas.

JOHN: Which only
armadillos might be under.
GUEST SPEAKER: Yeah.

PROFESSOR: Well, I think what
you've called attention to,

Jack, is her intention
of identifying

what's tourist space and
what is native space.

And I think that's
good, but I think

I wish there was some way,
that there was a happier
way to mingle.
JOHN: That's my point, yeah.

GUEST SPEAKER: The simple
solution I was thinking about

was just the steps
up to this one,

then you can go
across them both.

But I just sort of left it as
something further to explore.

Initially, they were actually--
there was a greater separation.

But just in terms of how heights
worked out within the floors,

and this was getting too high
and that was going to be short.
So that's how it ended up.
But yeah.
JOHN: I love this thing.

When you see this now here and
this wonderful use of form,
this seems a little bit modest.

It hasn't had quite the level
of invention that this has.
PROFESSOR: But that might be OK.
JOHN: It could be OK.

PROFESSOR: It's kind of like
this is the modest brother
or sister and this is the--
GUEST SPEAKER: Yeah.

My intention was
that you [INAUDIBLE]

don't quite know what
you're getting into,

and then you're surprised
when you get to this side.

And same thing that is part
of the whole [INAUDIBLE]..

JOHN: It's restoring
the connection of this.

GUEST SPEAKER: Yeah,
fabric, and then it
goes into something a little--

PROFESSOR: I think
that's believable.
I'm not sure I'd--

if I was doing
that, I might make
it a little more like that.
But maybe not, maybe not.

GUEST SPEAKER: The connection
between this building

and this building in
terms of circulation

was also very awkward
at first, especially

because I was keeping it the
square and the rectangles.

So then, until I finally
extended this one

to not match, but
relate back to this one
better to the connection--

PROFESSOR: Could you tell me why
this is yellow and this is not?

GUEST SPEAKER: That's
a good question.

That's simply because it fell
off on the transport over.
PROFESSOR: OK.
So this would be yellow.

The yellow represents
what's indoors.
GUEST SPEAKER: Exactly.
PROFESSOR: OK.

Can I just make a couple of
comments on your drawings?
GUEST SPEAKER: Yes, please.
PROFESSOR: They're clear.

I can understand
them and read them.

But I think that they
could be much more alive.

GUEST SPEAKER: This one I
just didn't have [INAUDIBLE]..
PROFESSOR: Well, I'm sure--
it's time in every case.

I like beginning to see
people here and cars
and understanding that.

But why don't I see people
in the plans, and more plants
and pavements?

PROFESSOR: This is
the end of a semester,

but it's really the slice
of life of 12 weeks or so.

And it's about architecture,
but it's also just about living.

And before you guys
all say something,

I just want to say I'm
very proud of these people.
They have come a long ways.
Some very exciting work here.

But as I said earlier,
particularly in these times,

what I find the
most exciting thing

is that they're good
citizens of the world.

They're sensitive to each
other and they've been a group.

If you go into that studio, it
vibrates, not only with beetles
but with activity and energy.
And that's a lot.

And I think it's terrific at
this time and in the world

that we have that,
because that's the future.

So I'm just asking if the
members who have reviewed today

would join me in
applauding the future.
[APPLAUSE]

This is the time of the year
that I give out some awards,

and these are words
that I give out

are going to become
more and more important

as the years go by
because they're rapidly
becoming antiques.

And I will give
them out forever.

There are three awards that
is given out each year.

There is the 314
Pencil Lead Award,

which is given to students
who have drawn a lot,

drawn well,
beautifully, et cetera.

There is the X-ACTO
Knife Aluminum Award

that is given to students who
have cut up a lot of things

or cut their fingers or have
done an outstanding job.

And there's the Yellow Trace--
this is not right, by the way.

There's the Yellow
Trace-- this is buff--

Yellow Trace, Golden
Trace Award for student

who's used the most paper
and has drawn the most.

This year was very difficult
because there was so many
people that I split the awards.

And so for the first award,
which is the Lead Pencil Award,
it goes to two people this year.

And that is Stephanie
and Kelly gets it.
[APPLAUSE]
Where's Kelly?

And the Aluminum Award, and
there's two of those this year.

And they go-- one
is obvious, right--

goes to Philip and the
other one to [INAUDIBLE]..
[APPLAUSE]

And the Gold Trace Award this
year, there are two of those

also, and they go
to Joyce and Sarah.
[APPLAUSE]

As some of you may know, it's
also the time of the year

that I do something that I've
started three or four years
ago, which I love to do.

I give a donation
to the library,

which I love because I don't
have to fill out any forms.

I don't have to do any POs, I
don't have to talk to anybody.

I just have to write a check
and call up this great library.
And I say-- downstairs--

I say, what's your
best new book?

And he tells me, and
I buy two copies,
one which is in the library.

I think this is a
fourth year that I
may have done this, fifth year.
I'm not sure.

And the other one
is given to someone.

And the reason for that
is that our community,

this architectural community,
is made up of the faculty

and it's made up
of the students,

but it's also made up
with the people that are
in this room who are reviewing.

And without them, we
wouldn't be a better place.
It's part of our community.

It's a very precious
thing that we have,

this coming together of outside
practitioners, other teachers,
and our own teachers.
It's a wonderful thing.

And the best you can get is
a parking ticket, which Heddy
just told me she probably got.

And it's outrageous that MIT
can't do better than that.

But it's very, very
important for the education
of people to hear your voices.

And so each year, there is a
book and there's a front piece.

And there's one in the library
and this is another one.

And this one reads this year,
presented with appreciation

to Steve Emerick,
who over the years

has served as a visiting
critic to the studio of Jan
Wampler, December.
[APPLAUSE]
Thank you.

You dropped your-- that's
why I asked you for a favor,
if you would stay with me.
So he has to go.
[LAUGHTER]

AUDIENCE: He can get
a parking ticket.
[LAUGHTER]

PROFESSOR: Well, if
people have some remarks

that they'd like to say, I think
the students are still awake.
Phil, are you awake?
Yes, you are.
We'd like to hear.

AUDIENCE: The thing
that I thought

was most fun was that the
progress from the very early,

the first review through
now, has been really

incredible to see because people
have made great strides taking

the original ideas and very
abstract forms and things that

really didn't have that much
constraint, many constraints,

to a project that
really was quite mindful

of the programmatic elements
that needed to happen,

but mostly were not
bound by that in a way

that it really made the forms
enslaved by that, which often

happens when people get too
involved with the program.

And I thought the freshness
of that first exercise really

carried through to this
last piece, which I think
is really wonderful.

So I applaud students for
being able to stick with that.

It was hard work, but it was
really, I think, well worth it.
PROFESSOR: Paul?

AUDIENCE: I was particularly
impressed with the junk models.

I thought they in
many instances emerged

from the students' intuition
or synthesis of the issues that

come to bear on a
problem like this.

And so it's a very
empowering device.

I think what I saw a
number of times [INAUDIBLE]

they have gone from
the junk models
to architecture and building.

It started [INAUDIBLE]
like a building,

as a building
might be perceived.

And I think these
junk models were

so realizable as architecture
at the end of the day

that it's very reassuring,
comforting to me

that there's that sensitivity,
that you don't have

the ability maybe to transform
it at this stage of the game

or to represent it
in two dimensions,

but your responses were
extremely sensitive.

And within those models resided
the power of architecture,

and in time you'll be
able to really take

these kinds of
sensitive responses

and develop really, really
strong architecture.

So I found that very
reassuring, and just

as pedagogically I've never
seen this junk model before,

but I think they're just very,
very powerful at this level.

They should be used
at every level,

but at this level in
particular, the students

don't have a means to really
communicate visually--
very exciting.

PROFESSOR: It reminds
me that I will never

show my level 1 work to anyone,
the work that we see here.

AUDIENCE: I find that this
junk model process, which is--

I think one of the most
interesting things for me

this semester has
been the program
and the open-ended nature of it.

And one of the
strengths of that is

that it's enabled some of you
to latch on to things which

may seem outlandish
at the get go,

but they are things that you
are personally invested in,

and it's led to you getting
very excited about your project

and developing some
really terrific things.

I think for some of you
the open-ended nature

of it might have been
something of a trap,

and then we got
some programs that

were a little all over
the map or too complex
or there was too much going on.

And it's nice in that we wind
up with a room of very, very
different projects and serving--

whose programs on the
very specific level
are quite different.

It's interesting the
thing that unites

them is the values that you
lay out in the beginning, which

is that it's in the community,
it's of the community.

It's a place to pull
people together.

And it's fun to see that
worked out and explored

in so many different directions,
both in the specificity of what

goes on there and
how they're built
and then the form they take.

Really tremendous
work throughout.

One of the very best
studios I've seen.
You all should be very proud.

AUDIENCE: I'd just
like to just echo

this, the diversity
of the projects,

given the same site and the
same sort of constraints,
it was quite wonderful to see.

I've seen those
on the other side

solutions, different rooftops,
and you get different solutions

because of those
locations, and you

realize what it means
to be different places.

But being in the same place
and then choosing something

that is hopefully
a passion of yours

or an interest of
yours, something

that you begin to see as being
necessary for the North End

leads to those
different solutions.

And the diversity of
that makes it very rich

because we can learn
from each other's kind

of different
exploration [INAUDIBLE]

and looked each other's stuff
and presented each other's work

at different levels, that
can only enrich this process.
It's brilliant.

AUDIENCE: I just want to
support the assemblage models.

Consistently, it was the genesis
of form almost every project.

And you could see
it in that model,

and that's where the
formal work began.

And you say they got tempered
down as they became buildings,

but in the spectrum of where
they could have started

and where they
could have ended, I

think that assemblage model
started them onto a path,

that it was a very
diverse solution
and the program drove it.

But that the actual method of
working based on interaction

pieces and gathering
them and assembling them,

you have just a
huge array of work

that is eminently
buildable, unbelievably
executed [INAUDIBLE].

For eight weeks,
it's a lot of work.

But it was a very
strong path formally

that started from a
pretty sketch models.

Compared to other
formal ways of working,

they really do
stand out on result.

AUDIENCE: This is by
far my favorite part

of classroom is getting to
talk to all these [INAUDIBLE]..

And it's just because it happens
when [INAUDIBLE] run back in

and I have all these new ideas
of projects over [INAUDIBLE]

But this is, now I
want to run back,

and I have all
these ideas, and I

have all these new perspectives
on the same problem.

And I find it so helpful
and so nice to be

able to talk to so many people
from different backgrounds

they come from to be able
to get that [INAUDIBLE]..
I really appreciate that.

It helped me a lot
to see-- if you

look at the same thing every
day, every day, every day,

you get into a mode where you
only see it one way [INAUDIBLE]

just helps me to see it
in so many different ways,
and I find that really helpful.

So I just wanted to
thank all of you.

I really do appreciate
[INAUDIBLE]..

PROFESSOR: So would
the students join me
in applauding the reviewers?
[APPLAUSE]

Well, I'm going to
miss all you guys.

I would like to take
all to Berkeley with me
and also all the reviewers.
The whole team, let's just go.

It's warmer and it's nicer
climate and beautiful campus.
We could have a great time.
What's that?
AUDIENCE: [INAUDIBLE]

PROFESSOR: And I'm
sad at leaving.

And of course, I
have my usual threat.

I haven't given
the grades out yet,

so I may give you
all incompletes
so we can continue in Berkeley.
It's been a great studio.

I really have-- all of
you have become very real.

You're all very,
very strong people.

And again, I just want
to say, thank you.
It means a lot to me.
